text: I think that we often treat engineers a little bit like children instead of giving them the responsibilities and ability to actually thrive as adults. And so like, 'Oh, the engineers won't want to do that work.' Well, that's actually not good for the engineers to be sheltered from what is important. And so actually one of the, I think, highlights is that I think we're coming back this moment where we can actually treat engineers like our peers and put them into really senior leadership roles and not have this kind of baseline assumption of like, 'Oh, we have to coddle them or hide them from the real problems.' And this is how they're going to get the opportunity to grow as well.
speaker: Will Larson
context: Lenny asks about how engineers' leverage within companies has changed from the zero interest rate era to today's market. Will explains that while engineers previously had significant leverage, the current shift is actually creating opportunities for engineers to take on more meaningful responsibilities. He argues that the previous era of coddling engineers to retain them was actually harmful to their professional development, as it prevented them from engaging with important business problems and advancing to senior leadership positions.
vocabulary_highlights: hide them from the real problems
text_ko: 저는 우리가 엔지니어들(engineers)을 어른으로서 실제로 잘 자랄 수 있게 책임과 권한을 주기보다, 마치 아이처럼 대하는 경우가 종종 있다고 생각해요. '엔지니어들이 그런 일을 하려 하지 않을 거야'라고 말하는 사람들이 있는데, 중요한 일에서 그들을 보호막으로 감싸는 건 오히려 좋지 않아요. 그래서 제가 중요하게 보는 것 중 하나는 지금이 엔지니어들을 동료로 대우해서 진짜로 시니어 리더십 역할(senior leadership roles)에 기용하고, '우리가 그들을 애지중지하거나 실제 문제에서 숨겨줘야 해'라는 기본 가정을 버릴 수 있는 순간으로 돌아오는 것 같다는 점이에요. 그래야 엔지니어들도 성장할 기회를 얻어요.
text_zh: 我觉得我们经常把工程师当小孩一样对待，而不是给他们真正的责任和机会让他们像成年人一样发挥才能。就像，"哦，工程师肯定不愿意干这活儿。" 其实这样把工程师保护起来，不让他们接触重要的事情，对他们反而不好。所以我觉得现在有个很好的趋势，就是我们终于可以把工程师当作真正的同事来看待，让他们担任真正的高级领导职位，而不是默认觉得"哦，我们得哄着他们，不能让他们碰真正的难题。" 这样他们才有机会真正成长起来。
text_es: Creo que muchas veces tratamos a los ingenieros un poco como si fueran niños, en lugar de darles las responsabilidades y la oportunidad de realmente destacar como adultos. Y entonces es como, "Ay, a los ingenieros no les va a gustar hacer ese trabajo." Pero en realidad eso no les conviene a los ingenieros, que los protejan de lo que es importante. Y entonces, de hecho, creo que algo muy destacable es que estamos llegando a un momento donde podemos tratar a los ingenieros como nuestros pares y ponerlos en roles de liderazgo muy senior, sin tener esa suposición básica de "Ay, tenemos que mimarlos o esconderles los problemas reales." Y así es como van a tener la oportunidad de crecer también.

text: Systems thinking is basically you try to think about stocks and flows. So stocks are things that accumulate and flows are kind of the movement from a stock to another thing. So what's a simple example of a stock? A stock could be the number of fish in a lake. A stock could be the number of people fishing in a lake. And so a flow between those two could be the number of fish in a lake will decrease at some rate based on the number of people fishing in that lake.
speaker: Will Larson
context: Lenny asks Will to explain what systems thinking actually means in practical terms. Will provides a foundational definition using the concept of stocks and flows - where stocks are things that accumulate over time, and flows represent the movement or changes between different stocks. He uses the analogy of fish in a lake and fishermen to illustrate how these elements interact and influence each other in a system.
text_ko: 시스템 사고(systems thinking)는 기본적으로 스톡(stock, 쌓이는 것)과 플로우(flow, 흐름)을 생각해 보는 거예요. 스톡은 축적되는 것들이고, 플로우는 한 스톡에서 다른 곳으로 이동하는 움직임이에요. 간단한 예를 들면 스톡은 호수에 있는 물고기 수나 그 호수에서 낚시하는 사람 수가 될 수 있어요. 이 둘 사이의 플로우는 예를 들어 호수의 물고기 수가 낚시하는 사람 수에 따라 어떤 비율로 줄어드는 것일 수 있어요.
text_zh: 系统性思维(systems thinking)其实就是你要考虑存量和流量的关系。存量(stocks)就是那些会积累的东西，流量(flows)就是从一个存量流向另一个地方的变化过程。举个简单的例子，什么是存量呢？湖里鱼的数量可以算是存量，在湖边钓鱼的人数也可以算存量。那这两者之间的流量关系就是，湖里的鱼会按照一定的速度减少，这个速度取决于有多少人在那儿钓鱼。
text_es: El pensamiento sistémico básicamente es que trates de pensar en términos de inventarios y flujos (stocks and flows). Los inventarios son cosas que se acumulan y los flujos son como el movimiento de un inventario hacia otra cosa. ¿Cuál sería un ejemplo sencillo de un inventario? Podría ser el número de peces en un lago. Podría ser el número de personas pescando en ese lago. Y entonces el flujo entre esos dos sería que el número de peces en el lago va a disminuir a cierta velocidad dependiendo del número de personas que estén pescando en ese lago.

text: The first rule of strategy is that if you write it down, then you can improve it. If it's not written down, it's hard to say if this PM is just not a good PM or if they're trying to apply the strategy that they've misunderstood or if they actually are correctly applying the strategy from the head of product that's just not appropriate to the problems they're working on, how do you debug any of that?
speaker: Will Larson
context: Lenny asks about engineering strategy and Will's observation that engineers often lack clear strategy compared to other functions. Will challenges the notion that companies lack strategy, arguing that strategy always exists but is often not written down. He emphasizes that without documentation, it's impossible to diagnose whether problems stem from poor execution, misunderstanding, or inappropriate strategy application.
text_ko: 전략의 첫 번째 원칙은 문서로 적어두면 개선할 수 있다는 거예요. 문서화되어 있지 않으면 이 프로덕트 매니저(PM)가 그냥 실력이 부족한 건지, 전략을 잘못 이해해서 엉뚱하게 적용하고 있는 건지, 아니면 프로덕트 책임자(head of product)의 전략을 정확히 따르고 있는데 그 전략 자체가 지금 그들이 다루는 문제에는 적절하지 않은 건지 구분하기가 어렵습니다. 그럼 이걸 어떻게 파악하겠어요?
text_zh: 战略的第一条规则就是，你得把它写下来，这样才能改进。如果没有写下来，你就很难判断这个PM(产品经理)到底是能力不行，还是理解错了策略在瞎搞，或者说他其实理解对了，但产品负责人制定的策略本身就不适合他们要解决的问题。这些你怎么去排查？
text_es: La primera regla de estrategia es que si lo pones por escrito, entonces lo puedes mejorar. Si no está escrito, es difícil saber si este PM simplemente no es un buen PM o si está tratando de aplicar una estrategia que entendió mal, o si en realidad está aplicando correctamente la estrategia del head of product (jefe de producto) que simplemente no es la adecuada para los problemas en los que está trabajando. ¿Cómo vas a debuggear todo eso?

text: The goal of good strategy is not to appease everyone. The goal of good strategy is to dictate how we invest the limited capacities we have or the limited capabilities we have into the problems we care about. And I think both of them were really effective towards that end.
speaker: Will Larson
context: Will discusses examples of engineering strategies from Uber (running their own data centers) and Stripe (using a Ruby monolith). He explains that while many engineers disliked these constraints, they were strategically valuable because they focused engineering effort on customer-facing innovation rather than internal tooling diversity. Will emphasizes that effective strategy requires making tough choices about resource allocation.
text_ko: 좋은 전략(strategy)의 목표는 모두를 만족시키려는 게 아니에요. 좋은 전략의 목표는 우리가 가진 제한된 자원이나 역량을 우리가 중요하게 생각하는 문제에 어떻게 투자할지 정하는 거예요. 그리고 저는 둘 다 그 목적을 달성하는 데 정말 효과적이었다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 好战略的目标不是让所有人都满意。好战略的目标是要明确我们怎么把有限的资源和能力投入到我们真正关心的问题上。我觉得这两个方面都很有效果。
text_es: El objetivo de una buena estrategia no es quedar bien con todo el mundo. El objetivo de una buena estrategia es decidir cómo vamos a invertir los recursos limitados que tenemos o las capacidades limitadas que tenemos en los problemas que realmente nos importan. Y creo que ambas fueron muy efectivas para lograr eso.

text: I feel really strongly that you can write a lot more if you write what you want to write. And so this is one of the reasons I don't write for financial gain and I don't write very much on a schedule, so I've done a few pieces for magazines, et cetera, but I find that actually really draining to be you have a topic, you have to agree on the topic. If a topic starts missing what you want to write about, you can't fix it a lot of the time and you're also on this deadline.
speaker: Will Larson
context: Lenny asks how Will manages to write so prolifically while working intense full-time jobs. Will explains his philosophy that sustainable writing comes from writing about topics that genuinely energize you, rather than writing for external motivations like money or deadlines. He contrasts this with commissioned writing for magazines, which he finds draining because of the constraints and external pressures involved.
vocabulary_highlights: starts missing what you want to write about
text_ko: 저는 쓰고 싶은 걸 쓰면 훨씬 더 많이 쓸 수 있다고 정말 확신해요. 그래서 돈을 벌려고 글을 쓰지 않고, 정해진 스케줄에 맞춰 많이 쓰지도 않아요. 잡지 같은 데에 몇 편 써본 적은 있지만, 사실 그런 건 되게 소모적이에요. 주제를 정하고 합의해야 하고, 그 주제가 점점 제가 쓰고 싶은 것과 달라지면 대부분 고칠 수가 없어요. 게다가 마감에 쫓기기도 하고요.
text_zh: 我特别坚信一点，写自己真正想写的东西，产出会高很多。所以我从来不为了赚钱而写作，也不会按什么固定计划来写。我确实给杂志写过几篇稿子什么的，但发现那样真的很消耗人——你得有个选题，还得和编辑商量确定选题。如果这个选题偏离了你真正想表达的内容，大多数时候你也没办法调整，而且还得赶截稿时间。
text_es: Estoy súper convencido de que puedes escribir mucho más cuando escribes sobre lo que realmente te gusta. Por eso yo no escribo por dinero y casi nunca escribo con fechas límites. He hecho algunos artículos para revistas y eso, pero la verdad es que me agota un montón cuando tienes que seguir un tema específico, cuando tienes que ponerte de acuerdo sobre el tema. Si el tema se desvía de lo que realmente querías escribir, muchas veces no lo puedes arreglar, y además estás con esa presión del deadline.

text: My biggest advice to both the EMs and the PMs, is before you try to solve the conflict, it's like pushing to ship this feature, pushing to change the approach. Just make sure you actually understand what they care about. There is this idea that you have to make trade-offs and that there are tons of hard trade-offs to be made in the field, but my experience is if you really deeply understand what everyone wants, there's usually a compromised solution that gives everyone exactly what they want.
speaker: Will Larson
context: Lenny asks for advice on how product managers can build better relationships with engineering managers. Will identifies two core problems: misaligned incentives and lack of understanding of each other's needs. He emphasizes that before trying to resolve conflicts between EMs and PMs, both parties should invest time in truly understanding what the other person cares about, as this often reveals compromise solutions that satisfy everyone's core needs.
text_ko: 엔지니어링 매니저(EM)와 프로덕트 매니저(PM)에게 가장 드리고 싶은 조언은요, 갈등을 해결하려 들기 전에—예를 들어 이 기능을 출시(ship)하려고 밀거나 접근 방식을 바꾸자고 밀어붙이기 전에—그들이 진짜로 무엇을 중요하게 생각하는지 먼저 제대로 이해하라는 거예요. 현장에서는 늘 많은 어려운 트레이드오프(trade-offs)가 있다고들 하지만, 제 경험상 모두가 진짜 원하는 걸 깊이 이해하면 보통은 모두에게 딱 맞는 절충안이 나오더라고요.
text_zh: 我给工程经理(EM)和产品经理(PM)最大的建议就是，在你想解决冲突之前——比如急着推某个功能上线，或者急着改变做事方法——你得先真正搞清楚对方在乎什么。大家总觉得做产品就得各种权衡取舍(trade-off)，这个领域有太多艰难的选择要做，但我的经验是，如果你真的深入理解每个人想要什么，通常都能找到一个折中的方案，让所有人都得到他们真正想要的东西。
text_es: Mi mejor consejo tanto para los EMs (engineering managers) como para los PMs (product managers), es que antes de tratar de resolver el conflicto, antes de presionar para lanzar esta función o cambiar el enfoque, asegúrense de que realmente entienden lo que les importa a todos. Existe esta idea de que tienes que hacer concesiones (trade-offs) y que hay un montón de decisiones difíciles que tomar en este campo, pero mi experiencia es que si realmente entiendes a fondo lo que cada uno quiere, por lo general hay una solución intermedia que le da a todos exactamente lo que necesitan.

text: Metrics are about educating the people consuming the metrics about the reality of the rich data underneath. They're not about this perfect data set that shows everything starting with something mediocre and the Dora metrics are really helpful for diagnosis, but if you have to, they can also be a good enough starting place to start reporting to your board or your CEO or to the other executives and then you're like, 'Oh, there's all these problems with them.'
speaker: Will Larson
context: Lenny asks about measuring engineering productivity and what metrics or tools Will finds useful. Will discusses the challenge engineers face when asked to provide metrics - they can explain why every measure is imperfect, leading to measuring nothing. He advocates for starting with imperfect but measurable metrics like the DORA metrics, then using questions about those metrics as opportunities to educate stakeholders about the complexities of engineering work.
text_ko: 지표(metrics)는 지표를 보는 사람들에게 그 밑에 깔린 풍부한 데이터(rich data)의 현실을 알려주는 수단이에요. 완벽하게 모든 걸 보여 주는 이상적인 데이터 세트가 목적이 아니에요. 보통 미흡한 것부터 출발하는 경우가 많은데, DORA 지표(DORA metrics)는 진단(diagnosis)에는 정말 도움이 돼요. 하지만 어쩔 수 없이 이사회(board)나 최고경영자(CEO), 다른 임원(executives)들에게 보고를 시작해야 할 때는 DORA 지표로 시작하는 것도 충분히 괜찮아요. 그러고 나면 '아, 이 지표들에 이런저런 문제가 있구나' 하고 알게 되는 거죠.
text_zh: 指标这个东西，说白了就是帮那些看数据的人理解底层丰富数据的真实情况。它们不是什么完美的数据集，能把所有从平庸开始的东西都展示出来。Dora指标在诊断方面确实很有用，但要是你非得用的话，它们也能作为一个不错的起点，拿去向董事会、CEO或者其他高管汇报。然后你就会发现："哎呀，原来这些指标有这么多问题。"
text_es: Las métricas se tratan de educar a la gente que las consume sobre la realidad de todos los datos ricos que hay por debajo. No se trata de tener ese conjunto de datos perfecto que muestre todo empezando con algo mediocre, y las métricas DORA son súper útiles para hacer diagnósticos, pero si no te queda de otra, también pueden servir como un punto de partida decente para empezar a reportar a tu junta directiva o a tu CEO o a otros ejecutivos, y después te das cuenta de que "Ay, tienen un montón de problemas estas métricas."
